Physicality doesn't mean anything. The physical as a category has been expanding for centuries in previously unthinkable directions to include more or less anything that can be described theoretically. By framing the conversation in these terms, Gutting incites irrational prejudices on either side of an ostensibly religious debate, when the subject at hand ought to be philosophy, not religion. We should be talking about epistemological boundaries. Believe it or not, fellow readers, there are practical and logical limits to what can be known. One of those barriers exists between the subjective experiences we enjoy and their causality. Certainly there are strong correlations between certain types of observable phenomena and certain experiences, such as brain activity and thought. However, it does not follow that brain activity is necessary and sufficient for thought, even though we all might like to believe it. It is beyond the epistemic limitations of science to prove such causality, and the familiar zombie-thought experiment illustrates this. Causality is extraordinarily hard to demonstrate rigorously, and in this case even if it's true it's probably impossible to prove. Is there ever inner life where the outward signs of it are absent? Maybe. The fact is you can't really be sure that there is inner life even when these signs are present, so ill prepared is science for making such causal claims. Proof is a very high standard, rarely to be satisfied by inductive methods.

I'm glad you're on the side of justice and love here, RC, but your intentional word choices are mistaken. Rights are not "granted." They exist, and are either recognized or are not. According to the 2010 census, there are about 900,000 same-sex households in the U.S. -- less than 1 percent of the total. Even if all of them were to marry overnight, the economic impact on anyone else would be marginal.

While I am in full support of the rights of any adult to marry anyone they want, it is rather naive to say this does not impact others. A universal right to marry has tax, employee benefits and other non-religious based impacts that will fundamentally change many aspects of all of our lives. Let's acknowledge that when we grant (word chosen intentionally) this right (also chosen intentionally) to all adults, we will all be impacted. Perhaps it will be higher taxes, lower entitlements, but to pretend it has no cost is nonsense.

I prefer the braver statement: the choice has costs but is worth it to promote a basic human right to choose who you love. I will pay this price.

RC

The second aspect of this, which wasn't mentioned, is that people like to assume the rules that apply to them personally also apply to the country as a whole. If you went on a serious spending spree at Christmas (or any time for that matter) then when the bills come due you start thinking "Wow, I really need to cut back and pay this down."

On a personal level, that makes sense. After all, you have a limited income (presumably) and that debt is costing you a lot in interest and not doing your credit report any good either. Psychological explanations are typically overdetermined. So there is certainly truth in what Wren-Lewis and PK say about the "sinner-man" motivation for austerity.

It's simply a question of how much weight we give to this particular explanation.

But while accepting this explanation to some degree, at a deeper level the enabling psychology which makes this "penitential" motivation possible is the toxic intersection of relative affluence and sociopathic (from mild to severe) narcissism.

Because the elites are relatively affluent, they do not directly feel the pain which the more economically marginal have had to bear - in many cases through no fault of their own.

Indeed, the causal fault has been overwhelmingly with the policy, mandarin, and business elites, especially, of course, the bankers. And Republicans much more so than Democrats.

These elites, because they are the rule makers, have rigged the system so that they, as a class, have escaped basically scot-free from the ravages of the Great Recession.

Indeed, many of them are doing better than ever.

But mix this favored economic status with narcissism and you have the secular equivalent of classic Calvinism.

Financial success becomes the marker for moral (and intellectual) superiority.

From there it is a very short step to a lack of empathy at best, and sociopathy at worst.

"They got what they deserved."

Not everyone in the ruling elites shares this pathology. But a disturbingly large number of them do.

"Did Stiglitz say he was arguing on the basis of morally-neutral "free market" economics? Why shouldn't morality be an element?"

I can answer that. The purpose of math is to connect cause and effects. Morality absolutely should be a factor in policy making, but the problem that mathematical disciplines are meant to solve are problems when people with the same morality make different decisions because they believe different versions of the facts. The purpose of building a morality-free decision infrastructure is not to downplay the importance of morality, but rather to move the morality to a decision point where facts and consequences are known a-priori and the consequences chosen will be real ones. At least that is the hope.

The Court is as enamored of CYA as the rest of us, I'm afraid.

The Supreme Court can ratify history as it is playing out across the nation, nay, across the world, or remain mired in prejudice. The Court has lost the respect of manyAmericans who see it as beholden to Republican interests. If they do not now do the right thing on marriage equality, they will find themselves in even worse repute--out of step with even the evolving Republican party. God forbid we should endure another Dredd Scott decision on this issue. The course of public sentiment on marriage equality is clear.

The Nation should not have to endure the torture of perpetual piecemeal legislation bouncing from the courts to the voters to State legislators and governors enacting and repealing over and over--with conservatives trying to game the process as with Proposition 8.

The eventual outcome is going to be freedom of marriage for all loving couples and official recognition of same. Delaying this eventually is a needless and irresponsible obstacle for the nation.
